questions.text: The movements at the ____________ joint permit a person to look to the right and left.
questions.solution:
The movements at the atlanto-axial joint allow a person to look left and right.

The atlanto-axial joints include 3 synovial joints:

  • Median atlanto-axial joint- The central pivot joint between the dens of the axis and a ring formed by the anterior arch and transverse atlantal ligament 
  • Lateral atlanto-axial joints- Plain synovial joints between lateral masses of atlas and upper facets of the body of axis

Movements at the atlanto-axial joint almost exclusively is rotation around the axis, which help side-to-side rotation of the head. The normal range of atlanto-axial rotation is about 40°.

questions.text: All of the following are true about the right coronary artery except _____

choices.text: It's diameter is less than left coronary artery
It arises from the anterior aortic sinus
It gives rise to circumflex coronary branch
Right conal artery is it's first branch

questions.solution:
The right coronary artery does not give rise to the circumflex coronary artery.

The right coronary artery arises from the anterior aortic sinus (right coronary sinus) of the ascending aorta. It passes anteriorly and descends vertically in the coronary sulcus between the right atrium and the right ventricle. On reaching the inferior margin, it turns posteriorly and continues in the sulcus onto the diaphragmatic surface and the base of the heart.

The diameter of the right coronary artery is less than that of the left coronary artery.

The right conal artery is, usually the first branch of the right coronary artery.

The circumflex coronary artery is a branch of the left coronary artery and is the exclusive supplier to the right bundle branch.

questions.text: What is the basis for the formation of omphalocele?

choices.text: Physiological hernia failing to go back

questions.solution:
Omphalocele is protrusion of abdominal contents through the umbilical ring. It is due to failure of physiological hernia to reduce into the abdominal cavity, which results in non-closure of the umbilical ring. .

An omphalocele may contain stomach, liver, and intestines. And these contents are enclosed in a sac.

Omphalocele is usually associated with other congenital anomalies (e.g., trisomy 13, trisomy 18, or Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome) and with increased levels of α-fetoprotein.

Note: In gastroschisis, there is an absence of a membranous sac and is paraumbilical.

Related Pearl: Difference between gastroschisis and omphalocele

Characteristic Gastroschisis Omphalocele
Defect size (diameter) 2-3 cm 2-15 cm
Sac Never Always, may be ruptured
Gestational age Prematurity Term
Umbilical cord Adjacent to the defect (defect is seen usually on its right side)  Attached to sac
Herniated viscera Small bowel, stomach, colon Small bowel, stomach, colon, liver
Malrotation Yes Yes
Bowel character Inflammatory, edematous Normal
Enternal nutrition Delayed Normal
Associated abnormalities Uncommon (10% atresia) Common (50%)

questions.text: Which fibre is marked by the arrow in the image given below?
questions.solution:
The marked structure is the internal capsule, which is a form of projection fiber.

Related Pearl: White matter tracts of the brain

Commissural fibers: connect corresponding regions of two hemispheres.

They include

  • Corpus callosum
  • Anterior and posterior commissure
  • Habenular commissure
  • Hippocampal commissure of fornix

Association fibers: connect various cortical regions within the same hemisphere.

They are classified as 

  • Short association fibers: lie immediately under the cortex and connect adjacent gyri. Eg- arcuate fasciculus
  • Long association fibers:
    • Uncinate fasciculus
    • Cingulum
    • Superior longitudinal fasciculus
    • Inferior longitudinal fasciculus
    • Fronto-occipital fasciculus
    • Fornix (except hippocampal commissure of fornix)

Projection fibers: fibers passing to and from the brainstem to the cerebral cortex. 

  • Internal capsule
  • Corona radiata

questions.text: Which nerve passes through the foramen marked in the image below?
questions.solution:
The marked structure is mandibular foramen and inferior alveolar nerve passes through it.

The inferior alveolar nerve (IAN), a branch of the mandibular nerve (CN V3), it descends behind the lateral pterygoid, at the lower border of the muscle, the nerve passes between the sphenomandibular ligament and the mandibular ramus and enters the mandibular canal via the mandibular foramen

The mandibular foramen is located above the mandibular angle, the opening through which the IAN and the vessels of the mandible pass.
The IAN continues its course through the mandibular canal and then branches off to supply the lower teeth, gums, and lower lip.

questions.text: Boundaries of Calot triangle are formed by all except:
questions.solution:
The gall bladder does not form a boundary of the Calot’s triangle.

Calot's triangle is bounded by 3C's:

  • Medially – Common hepatic duct
  • Inferiorly – Cystic duct
  • Superior – Cystic artery 

 

Clinical Note: Proper exposure of Calot's triangle and careful identification of the anatomic structures are keys to avoiding common bile duct injuries. This is the most common site of injury in laparoscopic cholecystectomy.

Related Pearl: Calot's triangle and hepatobiliary triangle

Boundaries Calot's Triangle Hepatobiliary Triangle

Superiorly

 Superior border of the cystic artery Inferior surface of the liver

Medially

 Common hepatic duct

Inferiorly

 Cystic duct

Contents of Calot’s triangle:

  • Lymph node of Lund - Sentinel lymph node for the gallbladder
  • Branching of cystic artery from the right hepatic artery

questions.text: Area marked in the given image is supplied by dermatome number?
questions.solution:
The marked dermatome which includes the umbilicus is supplied by T10.

The dermatomal distribution of the abdominal region is as follows: 

  • T7, T8, T9 - supplies skin from the xiphoid process to just above the umbilicus.
  • T10 - supplies skin around the umbilicus.
  • T11, T12 - supplies skin below the umbilicus upto the suprapubic region.
  • L1 - supplies skin around the genitalia and upper medial thigh.

questions.text: The arrow in the image denotes which of the following muscles?
questions.solution:
The arrow shows extensor carpi radialis longus.

It originates from the distal third of the lateral supracondylar ridge of the humerus and inserts at the second metacarpal (radial side). It is innervated by the radial nerve, C6, and C7.

The vascular supply is by radial recurrent artery and it is responsible for the extension and abduction of the wrist joint.

questions.text: What is the nerve supply of the structure marked in the image below?
questions.solution:
The marked structure is second lumbrical which is supplied by the median nerve.

The lateral two lumbricals are supplied by the median nerve and the medial two are supplied by the ulnar nerve. Function of these muscles is flexion at the metacarpophalangeal joints and extension at both the interphalangeal joints.

questions.text: Nerve supply of the area marked by arrow in the image is:
questions.solution:
The area marked in the image is supplied by radial nerve.

Related Pearl: Dermatome of upper limb

questions.text: Cholecysto-vena caval line separates which of the following?

choices.text: Porta hepatis and inferior vena cava
Right and left lobe of liver

questions.solution:
Cholecysto-vena caval line (Cantlie line) separates right and left lobe of the liver.

Cantlie line is an imaginary line that that divides the liver into 2 planes. It extends from the midpoint of the gallbladder fossa at the inferior margin of the liver back to the midpoint of the inferior vena cava (IVC) and contains the middle hepatic vein.

Related Pearl: Couinaud's liver segments

The Couinaud classification is currently the most widely used system to describe functional liver anatomy.

  • Based on the distribution of hepatic portal venous branches in the parenchyma
  • Each segment has its own dual vascular inflow, biliary drainage and lymphatic drainage

Segment I corresponds to the gross anatomical caudate lobe and is considered as posterior segment.

Other segments:

Liver sections

Couinaud's Segments

Right anterior sections

Segments V,VIII

Right Posterior sections

Segments VI, VII

Left medial sections

Segment IV (quadrate lobe)

Left lateral sections

Segment II, III

questions.text: Which of the following is false about skin?

choices.text: Skin accounts for 15% of total body weight
Dermis is made up of type 1 and type 3 collagen

questions.solution: Dermis is derived from mesoderm and epidermis is derived from ectoderm.

questions.text: All of the following structures are derived from the aponeurosis of the external oblique muscle except:
questions.solution:
Linea semilunaris is derived from the aponeurosis of the internal oblique muscle.

Pectineal ligament, inguinal ligament and lacunar ligament are derived from the external oblique aponeurosis.

questions.text: Which of the following lobes of the prostate forms the uvula vesicae?
questions.solution:
The median lobe of the prostate forms the uvula vesicae.

Uvula vesicae is an elevation in the mucous membrane of the urinary bladder, behind the internal urethral orifice. It is often enlarged in benign prostatic hypertrophy.

questions.text: Foot drop is caused by damage to:
questions.solution:
Foot drop is caused by damage to the common peroneal nerve.

The common peroneal nerve is a component of the sciatic nerve. In the posterior thigh, it supplies the short head of the biceps femoris. It curves around the neck of the fibula deep to peroneus longus and divides into superficial and deep peroneal nerves.

  • The superficial peroneal nerve innervates peroneus longus and peroneus brevis which are the evertors of the foot and to the skin over the dorsal area of the foot except for the first webspace and lateral side of the little toe.
  • The deep peroneal nerve innervates all muscles of the anterior compartment which are the dorsiflexors of the foot, extensor digitorum brevis, first two dorsal interossei muscles, and skin between great and second toes.

Hence, injury to the common peroneal nerve will lead to:

  • Weakness of dorsiflexion of foot or foot drop
  • Loss of eversion
  • Loss of extension of toes
  • Sensory loss
    • Anterior and lateral side of the leg
    • Dorsum of the foot including the medial side of the great toe

Th image given below shows the course of common peroneal nerve.

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding De Quervain’s tenosynovitis?

choices.text: Fingers are held in mild extension
Most common involvement is index finger

questions.solution:
De Quervain's disease is a stenosing tenosynovitis of the extensor tendons of the first dorsal compartment, namely extensor pollicis brevis (EPB) and abductor pollicis longus (APL).

It is prominent among females, especially pregnant women. Most commonly thumb is involved.

Finkelstein's test: On grasping the patient’s thumb and quickly abducting the hand ulnar ward, the pain over the radial styloid tip is excruciating. It’s the most pathognomonic objective sign but is also seen in other conditions like radial nerve entrapment and arthritis.

Treatment:

  • Majority of the patients are treated medically
  • Only few require the release of the 1st dorsal compartment which houses the APL and EPB tendons.

questions.text: Identify the structure marked B in the image given below :
questions.solution: The image given shows a midsagittal section of the brain. The structure marked B is the Fornix.

questions.text: 1st pharyngeal arch gives rise to all except:
questions.solution:
Levator veli palatini is not derived from first pharyngeal arch. 

All soft palate muscles including levator veli palatini are derived from the 4th pharyngeal arch and are supplied by vagal plexus.

First pharyngeal arch gives rise to:

  • Muscles of mastication (temporalis, masseter, lateral and medial pterygoids)
  • Mylohyoid
  • Anterior belly of digastric
  • Tensor tympani
  • Tensor veli palatini and 
  • Anterior 2⁄3 of tongue.

Related Pearl: Derivatives of Branchial Apparatus

Arch Nerve Skeletal derivatives Pouch Derivatives Muscle Derivatives Artery 

1st (mandibular arch)

 Trigeminal (V) - Maxillary and mandibular divisions
  • Incus
  • Malleus
  • Anterior ligament of malleus
  • Spine of sphenoid
  • Sphenomandibular ligament 
  • Auditory tube
  • Middle ear cavity 
  • Tensor tympani
  • Muscles of mastication 
  • Mylohyoid
  • Anterior belly of digastric
  • Tensor veli palatini
  • Maxillary artery

2nd (hyoid arch)

 Facial (VII)
  • Stapes
  • Styloid process (temporal)
  • Lesser cornu and upper hyoid
  • Stylohyoid ligament
  • Palatine tonsil
  • Tonsillar fossa 
  • Stapedius
  • Stylohyoid 
  • Facial Muscles (Buccinator, Platysma, Posterior belly of digastric)
  • Stapedial artery
  • Hyoid artery
3rd Glossopharyngeal (IX)
  • Greater cornu of hyoid
  • Lower part of hyoid body
  • Inferior parathyroids
  • Thymus 
  • Stylopharyngeus
  • Common carotid
  • Proximal internal carotid arteries 
4th Superior laryngeal of Vagus (X)
  • Thyroid cartilage
  • Corniculate cartilage
  • Cuneiform cartilage 
  • Superior parathyroids,
  • Parafollicular C cells of Thyroid (from ultimobranchial body)
 
  • Pharyngeal muscles
  • Larynx -Cricothyroid
  • Levator veli palatini
  • Right side: Right subclavian artery (proximal portion)
  • Left side: Arch of the aorta from the left common carotid to the left subclavian arteries
6th Recurrent laryngeal of Vagus (X)
  • Arytenoid cartilages
 		  
  • All intrinsic muscles of the larynx (except the cricothyroid muscle)
  • Right side: right pulmonary artery 
  • Left side: left pulmonary artery and ductus arteriosus
